author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: rejigger
description: This word has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word rejigger has appeared in seven articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 25 in “Airlines Hoping for More Boeing Jets Could Be Waiting Awhile” by Sydney Ember and Santul Nerkar:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: Therapists Trade the Couch for the Great Outdoors
description: Mental health practitioners are hiking, camping and braving the elements with their clients — all in an effort to help them connect with the Earth, and with themselves.
content: Sometimes a pine cone is just a pine cone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William D. Cohan
title: How Loud Billionaires Convert Their Wealth Into Power
description: What the rise of Bill Ackman, yet another megarich troublemaker, says about the power of social media to turn wealth into power.
content: Bill Ackman, the billionaire hedge fund manager, is an annoying and persistent contrarian. Not content just to help oust Harvard’s president, Claudine Gay, on charges of plagiarism, and for making public statements he disapproved of, he’s been using his social media presence (including his 1.2 million followers on X) to campaign for the removal of Sally Kornbluth as the president of M.I.T.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: California’s record deluge
description: Plus, the women who ruled the Grammys. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: A ferocious atmospheric river dumped rain on California, spawning landslides, flooding roads and causing power outages across the region. More than 350,000 homes and businesses in the state were without power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Schmitt
title: U.S. Strikes Hit Most of Targets in Iraq and Syria, Pentagon Says
description: U.S. officials acknowledge that the targeted militias still retain the majority of their capability to carry out future attacks.
content: American warplanes destroyed or severely damaged most of the Iranian and militia targets they struck in Syria and Iraq on Friday, according to the Pentagon, the first major salvos in what President Biden and his aides have said will be a sustained campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Hinton Battle, Three-Time Tony Winner in Musicals, Dies at 67
description: He won awards for his roles in “Sophisticated Ladies,” “The Tap Dance Kid” and “Miss Saigon” — the most ever in the category of best featured actor in a musical.
content: Hinton Battle, a dazzling dancer who won the first of his three Tony Awards in 1981 for his performance in the Duke Ellington musical revue “Sophisticated Ladies” after learning how to tap dance in the weeks leading up to opening night, died on Tuesday in Los Angeles. He was 67.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Bartlett, Jack Nicas and Cristóbal Olivares
title: Tragedy, Resilience and a Miracle at Chile’s Burned Botanical Garden
description: Wildfires destroyed 98 percent of Chile’s national botanical garden and killed a worker and her family. But there were signs of hope in the ashes.
content: On Friday afternoon, several hundred people were roaming the idyllic grounds of Chile’s national botanical garden, mostly unaware that, just across some hills and a highway, a raging wildfire was galloping toward them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman and Bridget Bennett
title: Why Are Americans Wary While the Economy Is Healthy? Look at Nevada.
description: Economic shocks over two decades, combined with reliance on volatile casinos, have undermined confidence despite an economy that’s bustling.
content: Toni Irizarry recognizes that the economy has improved. Compared with the first wave of the pandemic, when Las Vegas went dark, and joblessness soared to levels not seen since the Great Depression, these are days of relative normalcy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maia Szalavitz
title: How Oregon Became a Linchpin for the Country’s Drug Policies
description: Fears over skyrocketing overdoses threaten to undo Oregon’s work in establishing humane, effective drug policies.
content: In February 2021, Oregon decriminalized possession of small amounts of all drugs, via a ballot initiative known as Measure 110. The idea was to treat addiction as a public health problem, based on overwhelming evidence that jailing people for having small amounts of drugs for personal use is both ineffective and counterproductive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Parisians Vote to Triple Parking Fees for Big S.U.V.s and Other Hefty Cars
description: The city authorities say that large cars pollute more and are dangerous for pedestrians. Opponents say the mayor is on a crusade against motorists.
content: Voters in Paris have approved an effort to drastically increase parking fees for large sport utility vehicles and other heavy cars, the latest move by Mayor Anne Hidalgo to reshape the French capital with environmentally conscious and pedestrian-friendly policies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: ​This Florida Mall Has Gucci, Prada … and Soon, Affordable Housing?
description: A​ new law​ lets developers bypass local zoning rules if they promise “work force housing.”​ ​I​t has stirred an uproar around the state, most recently in affluent Bal Harbour​.
content: In Bal Harbour, Fla., an oceanside village north of Miami Beach, a luxury mall says it wants to help tackle one of the nation’s — and Florida’s — most intractable problems: a lack of affordable housing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: In Las Vegas, Biden Promotes Promises Kept to Black and Hispanic Voters
description: While Nevada has a primary this week, the president is looking ahead to the general election and trying to energize supporters in a key swing state.
content: Fresh off an overwhelming victory in South Carolina’s Democratic primary, President Biden rallied supporters on Sunday in Nevada, saying that he had kept his promises to the Black and Hispanic voters who helped elect him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman and Hiroko Tabuchi
title: Two Climate Advisers Quit U.S. Export-Import Bank Over Fossil Fuel Plans
description: The bank is set to vote Thursday on financing an oil project in Bahrain, the latest in a string of overseas fossil fuel projects.
content: A federal bank that finances projects overseas is set to vote on Thursday on whether to use taxpayer dollars to help drill oil and gas wells in Bahrain, a contentious decision that prompted two of the bank’s climate advisers to resign, according to people with knowledge of their decisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Wins Album of the Year, Breaking a Record
description: The win for “Midnights” was Swift’s fourth for album of the year, after previous victories for “Fearless,” “1989” and “Folklore.”
content: Taylor Swift already has more No. 1 albums than any other woman (12), as well as the highest-grossing tour in history (an estimated $1 billion and counting).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: 22 Looks That Did the Most at the Grammys
description: The awards show is known to be a fashion playground. This year’s event was no exception.
content: The music industry’s biggest stars attended the 66th Grammy Awards in Los Angeles in attire as varied as their songs and albums. Much of that attire — whether it was a cutout gown or a sheer shirt — exposed midsections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Storm-Battered Los Angeles Faces Another Day of Heavy Rainfall
description: Officials said the atmospheric river would linger over the region on Monday, causing more mudslides and severe flooding.
content: Mudslides and severe flooding were reported across parts of Los Angeles late Sunday and Monday morning, as experts warned that a massive storm was likely to stall over the region, bringing more misery throughout the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vjosa Isai and Ian Austen
title: As Canadian Hockey Players Face Assault Charges, Officials Are on Defensive
description: Hockey fans in Canada are struggling to make sense of a scandal that has led to sexual-assault charges against five former junior hockey players.
content: The police chief whose department has filed sexual assault charges against five hockey players, all of whom played on National Hockey League teams, apologized on Monday to the victim for the six years it took to bring the case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: At Ghana Event, Fowler Museum Returns Items Taken From Asante Kingdom
description: The seven items had been part of its collection since 1965, but new research found that the objects, including gold jewelry, had been taken by British forces during the colonial era.
content: Seven items taken from the Asante Kingdom in West Africa by British forces during a 19th-century conflict were returned to the Asante king in what is now Ghana on Monday by officials of the Fowler Museum at U.C.L.A.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Ko
title: A Beloved Chicken and Rice Dish, Streamlined for Weeknights
description: How classic Hainanese chicken rice evolved but still tastes like home.
content: From last Lunar New Year to this one, my life has gone through challenges and changes, and I wanted to shield my kids from all of it. It turns out that, despite my best efforts, they in some way perceive what’s happening, so I instead try to give them what stability I can. When that’s out of my control, I cook.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: The Retribution Presidency
description: A former White House official has a warning about Donald Trump.
content: John Bolton has a warning about what a second Donald Trump presidency might look like.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: The Grammys Aim for a Big Tent, but Not Everyone Feels at Home
description: The most awarded artists were diverse on Sunday night. How those winners received their honors, however, differed mightily.
content: Sunday night at the 66th annual Grammy Awards, Jay-Z accepted the Dr. Dre global impact award, a sort of éminence grise prize. He’s previously won 24 Grammys, but he did not treat the moment like a homecoming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Larry David Breaks Georgia’s Voting Law in ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’
description: Comedy’s crankiest star usually breaks social norms. This time, he ran afoul of voting legislation passed in Georgia in 2021.
content: Television comedies like “Veep” and “Parks and Recreation” have long poked fun at the absurdities of national and local politics, but it’s rare for them to zero in on the fine print of laws passed by state legislatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: Who Is Your Hero?
description: Who inspires you to pursue your dreams or improve your life?
content: Do you have a role model: a person who has a good influence on you and who motivates you to do your best? Is this person someone you know personally or one you admire from afar? How do you think your role model has shaped your life?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Boyd
title: Before He Was George Orwell, He Was Eric Blair, Police Officer
description: Paul Theroux’s new novel, “Burma Sahib,” explores the writer’s formative experiences in colonial Myanmar.
content: George Orwell died of tuberculosis in 1950, at the age of 46. Yet today, over 70 years later, his long shadow remains as dark and well defined as ever, particularly in Britain, where he is enlisted and quoted as an authority as often as Shakespeare, Winston Churchill or the Bible. The word “Orwellian” is as omnipresent as “Kafkaesque.” His two dystopian novel-allegories — “Animal Farm” and “1984” — have sold in the millions around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: The Elusive Restaurant Group Redefining Korean Dining in New York
description: Hand Hospitality has become a major player by channeling the creative energy of Seoul. But don’t expect its soft-spoken owners to crow about that.
content: Even on a chilly Monday evening, the wait at Cho Dang Gol was more than an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant
title: Google’s Once Happy Offices Feel the Chill of Layoffs
description: Job cuts, which could continue throughout the year, have created a glum mood at what was arguably Silicon Valley’s most exuberant workplace.
content: When Diane Hirsh Theriault’s co-worker returned from lunch to Google’s Cambridge, Mass., office one afternoon in October, his work badge couldn’t open a turnstile. He quickly realized it was a sign that he had been laid off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Zelensky Hints at Major Shake-Up of Ukraine’s Government
description: The president said a “reset” was needed to revive the struggling war effort, adding that his plans were “about the direction of the country’s leadership” and not just about replacing his top general.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine said that a broad overhaul of the country’s military and civilian leadership was needed to reboot the war effort against Russia, suggesting that a major shake-up of his government was imminent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: How Nevada Is Pushing to Generate Jobs Beyond the Casinos
description: Chastened by a series of economic downturns that punished the hospitality industry, state leaders are working to broaden the economy.
content: Before the pandemic brought everyday life to a halt, Joe Kiele supported himself through the industry that dominates Nevada’s economy. He waited tables at a steakhouse inside a casino in Reno.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karoun Demirjian
title: Here’s What’s in the Senate’s $118 Billion Ukraine and Border Deal
description: Tens of billions of dollars in aid to Ukraine would be tied to an immigration crackdown under legislation that faces a test vote in the Senate this week.
content: Senate Democrats released a $118.3 billion emergency national security bill on Sunday that would tie a fresh infusion of aid to Ukraine to measures clamping down on migration across the United States-Mexico border.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Ex-Day Care Director Who Fed Children Melatonin Gets 6 Months in Jail
description: The former director, Tonya Rachelle Voris, 53, was sentenced Friday after pleading guilty to giving the supplement to more than a dozen children without their parents’ consent.
content: A former church day care director in Indiana has been sentenced to six months in jail after admitting that she had fed melatonin gummies to more than a dozen young children without their parents’ consent, court records show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Penn
title: Summer Has Long Stressed Electric Grids. Now Winter Does, Too.
description: Electric utilities, which designed their system to meet peak demand in sizzling weather, are straining to keep up during the cold.
content: For decades, managers of electric grids feared that surging energy demand on hot summer days would force blackouts. Increasingly, they now have similar concerns about the coldest days of winter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Annie Lennox Honors Sinead O’Connor With Powerful Grammys Performance
description: At the end of her tribute to the outspoken artist, Lennox proclaimed: “Artists for cease-fire”
content: In an emotional ode to Sinead O’Connor at the Grammys, Annie Lennox performed “Nothing Compares 2 U,” the Irish singer-songwriter’s cover of the Prince original that became a No. 1 hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Texas Will Expand Effort to Control Land Along Mexican Border, Abbott Says
description: Flanked by Republican governors, Gov. Greg Abbott said that Texas would expand the immigration enforcement efforts at the center of a legal confrontation with the federal government.
content: Locked in a legal battle with the Biden administration over immigration enforcement, Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas said on Sunday that he was expanding his effort to establish state control over areas near the Rio Grande in an effort to deter migrants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses
title: Many Schools in Southern California Will Remain Open Despite Floods
description: The districts that announced they were not closing include Los Angeles Unified, the largest in the state.
content: Most school districts in Southern California, including Los Angeles Unified, the second-largest in the country, were planning to keep most classrooms open on Monday, officials said, even as the state battled heavy rain, flooding and mudslides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy and Jenny Gross
title: Boeing Finds More Problems With 737 Max, Risking Delivery Delays
description: The plane manufacturer said incorrectly drilled holes were found in the fuselage of about 50 undelivered planes.
content: Boeing said that a new problem with the fuselages of some unfinished 737 jets would force the company to rework about 50 planes, potentially delaying their delivery and raising further concerns about quality at the manufacturer and its suppliers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dylan Loeb McClain
title: The Winding Climb to Play in the World Chess Championship
description: A scramble at the end of last year for the last two slots in the Candidates Tournament led to changes in the rules for qualification.
content: The Candidates Tournament to select a challenger for the World Chess Championship will be held in April in Toronto. While spots in the tournament are always competitive, changes to the selection process resulted in some players’ finding loopholes to qualify, leading to a scramble at the end of last year. The ensuing chaos led to criticism of the International Chess Federation, the game’s governing body, also known as FIDE. In response, the federation made rule changes to balance out the selection process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Snap Becomes Latest Tech Company to Cut Jobs
description: The company laid off more than 500 of its employees on Monday, or about 10 percent of its global work force.
content: Snap, the parent of the Snapchat messaging app, said on Monday that it would lay off more than 500 employees, joining other tech companies in a wave of new cost-cutting measures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roberta Smith
title: Eileen Agar: Her Jewel-Like Paintings Stretched Surrealism
description: The British artist lived long and worked in numerous mediums, but is barely known in the United States.
content: The history of art by women still has its secrets. Some recent revelations include the visionary abstract painter Hilma af Klint of Sweden, the genius American quilter Rosie Lee Tompkins and Mary Delany, an 18th-century British polymath who created some of Western art’s first collages.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Here Is How Much Rain Has Fallen in Los Angeles
description: The rainfall was expected to last well into Monday, with the total in some parts of Los Angeles meeting or exceeding the average rainfall for February.
content: The powerful storm that brought heavy winds and the risk of severe flooding to much of Southern California on Sunday was expected to linger over the Los Angeles area until Tuesday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Monday Briefing
description: The U.S. leads strikes in the Middle East.
content: The U.S. launched scores of strikes against Iranian-backed militias in the Middle East over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Vintage Won the Grammys Red Carpet
description: Miley Cyrus, Laverne Cox, Olivia Rodrigo, Billie Eilish — big stars in old clothes was the trend of the night. Because it’s not just about the gowns.
content: The awards show red carpet has become such an access game, such a race of clout and connections to see who can wear the most never-before-seen or sizzlingly-hot-off-the-runway look — the answer, this time, was Beyoncé, in Louis Vuitton men’s wear from Pharrell Williams’s January show — that any other approach can seem like a shock.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samantha Maldonado
title: The Five Brooklyn Roommates Who Merged Two Households Into One
description: In Bushwick, the neighborly ‘hello’ in the hallway led to hanging out in each other’s apartments, and spirited theater-karaoke nights singing show tunes.
content: Emily Zaboski sometimes struggles to describe her living situation to people she meets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: The Other Side of Soaring Employment Numbers
description: The latest data on jobs and wages are positive on the surface, but a large group of voters are still downbeat about the state of the economy.
content: The U.S. economy is a paradox. Official figures show that growth is solid, jobs are plentiful and wages are climbing, and yet voters are mostly feeling down and giving President Biden little credit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Diego Argüello
title: Video Games Are Mourning the Old, Weird, Clunky Internet
description: Developers have created nostalgic experiences recalling online life before homogenized websites and algorithmic social media feeds.
content: Surfing the web in the 1990s and early 2000s was a slower endeavor, and fewer people had access to the technology. But it is still easy to reminisce about the days when it felt like a public marketplace, with high odds that someone out there had made a blog or GeoCities site about the niche topic you found interesting.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Roberts
title: Bob Beckwith, Firefighter Who Stood With Bush After 9/11, Dies at 91
description: Photographs showing him with the president atop a rubble-strewn destroyed fire truck came to represent America’s fortitude in the aftermath of the attack.
content: Bob Beckwith, a retired firefighter from Long Island who aided in the search for survivors after the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, and who was catapulted to fame after photographs showing him and President George W. Bush standing atop the rubble-strewn remains of a fire truck became symbols of the stunned nation’s grit, died on Sunday in Rockville Centre, N.Y. He was 91.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: The Silly Putty Republicans
description: House Republicans should know the difference between incompetence and impeachment.
content: Just when you thought House Republicans couldn’t warp the impeachment process any more, here we are, watching them twist and stretch this weighty constitutional provision beyond all recognition — like some grimy wad of Silly Putty pulled from under Marjorie Taylor Greene’s sofa.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Nate Cohn, Alex Stern, Mooj Zadie, Clare Toeniskoetter, Mary Wilson, Devon Taylor, Patricia Willens, Rowan Niemisto, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: The 1948 Economic Moment That Might Explain Our Own
description: In the aftermath of World War II, many Americans found themselves frustrated by the policies of the president, Harry S. Truman.
content: President Biden has struggled to sell Americans on the positive signs in the economy under his watch, despite figures that look good on paper. That could have important ramifications for his re-election hopes.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Reflections on the E. Jean Carroll Verdict
description: Readers react to Opinion pieces about her audacity and libel law. Also: The U.S. and Iran; Democratic alternatives; controversy at Penn; pets in cold weather.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich, Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
title: Ex-N.Y.P.D. Official Admits Funneling Illegal Funds to Adams Campaign
description: Dwayne Montgomery, a retired police inspector, pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor. The mayor’s fund-raising practices have drawn scrutiny from law-enforcement agencies.
content: Dwayne Montgomery, a retired police inspector who was once friendly with Mayor Eric Adams, pleaded guilty on Monday to misdemeanor conspiracy, saying that he had directed straw donors to contribute to the mayor’s 2021 campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Blinken’s Mideast visit and U.S. aid to Israel are the focus in Washington this week.
description: A trip back to the Middle East by the United States’ top diplomat to continue talks on a possible cease-fire deal highlights a week of high-level wrangling over the war in Gaza and beyond.
content: A trip back to the Middle East by the United States’ top diplomat to continue talks on a possible cease-fire deal highlights a week of high-level wrangling over the war in Gaza and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellina Moore and Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Abbott Elementary’ and Super Bowl LVIII
description: The third season of the award winning sitcom airs on ABC. The Kansas City Chiefs and the San Francisco 49ers go head-to-head.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, Feb. 5-11. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Miley Cyrus Wins Record of the Year for ‘Flowers.’
description: She also won best pop solo performance for “Flowers,” from her album “Endless Summer Vacation.”
content: Miley Cyrus won the Grammy for record of the year on Sunday for the kiss-off anthem “Flowers,” her first win in the category.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Robie Harris, Often-Banned Children’s Author, Is Dead at 83
description: Her children’s books on matters of sex and sexuality — notably “It’s Perfectly Normal” — became fodder for the culture wars.
content: Robie Harris, a children’s book author and former teacher whose writing about sexuality made her among the most banned authors in America, died on Jan. 6 in Manhattan. She was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Benjamin Mullin
title: CNN’s New Morning Strategy: More News, Less Banter
description: The change is the first major programming shift under CNN’s new leader, Mark Thompson.
content: CNN spent years trying to compete in the cutthroat realm of chatty morning TV, cycling through formats in the hopes of catching up to breakfast-time staples like “Morning Joe” and “Good Morning America.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins
title: A New Book Reckons With the Border Crisis, in all Its Complexity
description: In “Everyone Who Is Gone Is Here,” Jonathan Blitzer connects the dots between U.S. foreign policy in Central America and the migrant crisis.
content: The immigration crisis at the southern border has become a defining issue of this year’s presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost, Chris Buckley and Amy Chang Chien
title: Chinese-Australian Writer Held by China Given Suspended Death Sentence
description: The verdict in the case of Yang Hengjun, who was detained on national security charges, may weigh on the warming relations between China and Australia.
content: An Australian writer and businessman who has been detained in China since 2019 has been declared guilty of espionage and was given a death sentence with two years’ probation on Monday, in a blow to warming relations between Australia and China.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Biden vs. Trump (Taylor’s Version)
description: Didn’t you hear that the fix is in?
content: Gail Collins: So, Bret — more than 350,000 new jobs in January without an inflation surge! Great news, huh? I guess that means the Biden plan is really working out, hehehehe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raymond Zhong
title: Six Spongy Sea Creatures Suggest Warming Might Be Worse Than Thought
description: Research on a long-lived but rarely seen species in the Caribbean is helping scientists piece together a revised history of climate change.
content: Since the dawn of the industrial age, our species has warmed the planet by considerably more than today’s most widely accepted estimates imply, according to a team of scientists who have gleaned detailed new information about Earth’s past climate from an unusual source: centuries-old sponges living in the Caribbean Sea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: The Hills Came Tumbling Down in Studio City
description: Residents of one street were forced to evacuate as mud and rocks thundered down the hillside.
content: Rain had been falling for hours in the Studio City neighborhood of Los Angeles when Scott Toro, 60, was startled on Sunday night by a noisy rumble. “I don’t know how to describe it,” he said on Monday morning. “Almost like a plane crashing or something.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Taylor Swift Announces New Album During Grammy Win
description: During her win for best pop vocal album, the singer-songwriter announced that she would release a new album, “The Tortured Poets Department,” on April 19.
content: As she accepted the Grammy for best pop vocal album for “Midnights,” Taylor Swift announced that she would be releasing her new album, “The Tortured Poets Department,” on April 19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Zoladz
title: Tracy Chapman and Luke Combs Gave America a Rare Gift: Harmony
description: Culture can too often drive us apart. At the Grammys on Sunday, two artists delivered something different.
content: When a beloved artist who has not performed live in some time returns to the stage, we often expect them to appear fragile, unsteady, ill at ease. But during Sunday night’s Grammy Awards, when the camera first pulled back from a tight shot of a woman’s fingers picking a familiar riff on an acoustic guitar and revealed the face of the great, elusive folk singer Tracy Chapman, what you noticed was the joy radiating from her face. Her contented smile. The unwavering tone and rich steadiness of her voice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Fed Chair Powell Says Officials Need More ‘Good’ Data Before Cutting Rates
description: Federal Reserve officials are debating when to lower rates. An interview with Jerome H. Powell confirms a move is coming, but not immediately.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, made clear during a “60 Minutes” interview aired on Sunday night that the central bank is moving toward cutting interest rates as inflation recedes, but that policymakers need to see continued progress toward cooler price increases to make the first move.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tripp Mickle
title: Why Is Big Tech Still Cutting Jobs?
description: Profits are up and the economy is strong. But the tech industry faces two challenges — dealing with a frenetic work force expansion in the pandemic and building A.I.
content: After a year of big layoffs, job cuts at the tech industry’s largest companies trickled into the first month of 2024.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Kolata
title: Users of New Weight Loss Drug Had Lower Blood Pressure in Study
description: The patients used tirzepatide, sold as Mounjaro or Zepbound, but researchers could not distinguish the effect of the drug from the effects of weight loss.
content: A study of the weight loss drug tirzepatide showed that people who took it had significantly lower blood pressures after 36 weeks of using the medication.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Top U.S. Treasury Officials to Visit Beijing for Economic Talks
description: A meeting of the new economic working group comes as the U.S. and China are trying to prevent any escalation of hostilities.
content: The Biden administration is dispatching a high-level delegation of Treasury Department officials to Beijing this week for a round of economic talks as the world’s largest economies look to continue engagement efforts that President Biden and his Chinese counterpart, Xi Jinping, agreed to pursue last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Yoon
title: Samsung’s Leader Acquitted in Stock and Accounting Fraud Case
description: Lee Jae-yong’s case had raised questions about the immense power that chaebol leaders wield and the legal system holding them to account in South Korea.
content: A South Korean court on Monday acquitted Lee Jae-yong, Samsung’s top executive, on charges of stock price manipulation and accounting fraud, the latest twist in the billionaire’s legal troubles tied to a merger that helped him secure control of the nation’s largest company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Economist Who Helped Patients Get New Kidneys
description: The social math of kidney transplants is tricky. Game theory helped.
content: An operating room. Surgeons around a table. On it, a stainless steel bucket with something bloody inside. A step or two back, a man in a yellow gown, his brow furrowed and his arms behind his back.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Feb. 5, 2024
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, Feb. 5, 2024.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: VoteVets Plans $45 Million Push to Lift Biden and Democrats
description: The super PAC is aiming to dampen the support of veterans for Donald Trump, who lost ground with them in 2020.
content: VoteVets, the liberal political action committee known for supporting veterans running for office, will spend $45 million to back President Biden and Democratic candidates for the House and Senate, Jon Soltz, the group’s co-founder and chairman, said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: For California, ‘One of the Most Dramatic Weather Days’
description: The most significant storm to hit California so far this year lashed the state on Sunday.
content: It’s Monday. Yesterday was a weather day for the record books — and today could be one, too. Plus, the California State Senate has a new leader.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hugh Morris
title: In ‘Last Days,’ Strange Sounds of Simultaneous Joy and Sadness
description: Oliver Leith’s opera, based on the Gus Van Sant film that fictionalized the end of Kurt Cobain’s life, has its U.S. premiere in Los Angeles.
content: It can feel easy to cast a swift judgment on the composer Oliver Leith. First, there are his titles, such as “Uh huh, Yeah,” “Bendy Broken Telemann No.3,” and “yhyhyhyhyh.” Then, there is the inspiration for his sounds, in which everyday objects like glass bottles and cereal bowls are considered intensely, becoming weird instruments themselves.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Kitamura
title: A Contemplative Novel Set in the I.C.U.
description: In his new novel, “Trondheim,” the author Cormac James explores the terrible dread and peculiar quality of watching over a loved one in the hospital.
content: Alba is a translator. Lil is a personal trainer. Alba deals with anxiety by counting rosary beads; Lil, with bouts of intense, at times bruising, physical training. Together, they are the parents of three children. One day, they receive a phone call: Their son Pierre, who lives abroad in Trondheim, had a cardiac arrest at a bus stop and now lies in a coma at a hospital. And so, the nightmare begins. The two women pack their bags, arrange care for their other children and travel, fragile relationship in tow, to Norway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Killer Mike Arrested After Winning Three Grammys
description: The police confirmed the arrest after video showed the rapper in handcuffs, being led through the Crypto.com Arena by a police officer.
content: Shortly after winning three Grammys, the rapper Killer Mike was arrested at the awards show on Sunday in connection with a physical altercation at the Los Angeles arena where the ceremony took place, the police said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Immigrants Make America Stronger and Richer
description: Secure the border — but don’t stop the inflow of workers we need.
content: Modern nations can’t — practically or politically — have open borders, which allow anyone who chooses to immigrate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Grace Linden
title: Exploring Ghana, With Contemporary Art as a Guide
description: A globalized art market has brought attention to Ghanaian artists like Ibrahim Mahama. On an arts-focused trip to the West African country, a writer finds a thriving scene following its own agenda.
content: In late 2022, I was invited to go to Ghana with a friend researching work by the Ghanaian artist Ibrahim Mahama, who first made a splash at the 56th Venice Biennale in 2015. We were going to Ghana to learn about the context of his work and also to understand the emerging contemporary art scene in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Russian Tech Giant Reaches $5 Billion Deal to Quit Russia
description: Yandex, often called “Russia’s Google,” said it reached a deal to sell off its assets in the market where it made its fortune, after the war in Ukraine upended its operations.
content: The parent firm of Russia’s most prominent technology company, Yandex, said it has agreed to sell all its assets in the country for about $5 billion, which would be one of the largest corporate exits from Russia since its invasion of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Joni Mitchell Takes the Grammy Stage for the First Time
description: Mitchell, who largely vanished from the public eye after having an aneurysm nine years ago, performed “Both Sides Now.”
content: It’s hard to believe that at 80 years old, after a groundbreaking career in music, there are still new achievements left for Joni Mitchell. But on Sunday night, she did something for the first time: performed on the Grammys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Tuesday Briefing: Blinken’s High-Stakes Middle East Trip
description: Also, King Charles’s cancer diagnosis and the women who ruled the Grammys.
content: Antony Blinken, the U.S. secretary of state, landed in Saudi Arabia yesterday, beginning his visit to the Middle East. He is trying to prevent the Israel-Hamas conflict from becoming a broader regional war — and to rally allies around a proposal to release hostages in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Milton Esterow
title: Torah Scrolls That Survived the Nazis Now Fuel Faith Around the World
description: The Memorial Scrolls Trust celebrated a 60th anniversary on Sunday. It has lent some 1,400 scrolls, once confiscated by the Nazis in Europe, to communities in 25 countries.
content: Since the Congregation Bonai Shalom in Boulder, Colo., was founded in 1981, one of its several Torahs has been taken from the ark each Sabbath, and on other holy days, and read to members of the congregation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Asimov
title: This Valentine’s Day, Say It With Wine
description: For occasions like a day that spotlights sweets, a special bottle of sweet wine might be the perfect ending.
content: We all know that Valentine’s Day is simply a corporate money grab, a holiday with one purpose: obliging you to buy cards, flowers, jewelry, chocolates and candies, wear red and order from overpriced menus on one of the busiest restaurant nights of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claudia Lopez Lloreda
title: It’s ‘Liquid Gold’ for Newborns. But Can It Help Your Health?
description: We asked experts about the evidence behind trendy cow colostrum supplements, and the potential risks of taking them.
content: Colostrum, the milk-like substance produced by mothers in the first few days after giving birth, provides antibodies, antimicrobial proteins and other vital nutrients to newborns across the mammalian world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Celine Dion, Coping with Neurological Disorder, Presents the Final Grammy
description: The Canadian diva made a surprise return to the awards show Sunday night to present the award for album of the year to Taylor Swift.
content: Celine Dion, the Canadian pop superstar who announced in 2022 that she has a rare neurological disease that makes it difficult for her to sing, appeared at the Grammy Awards to present the final award of the night, album of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $1.3 Million Homes in California
description: An adobe compound in Joshua Tree, a one-bedroom condominium in West Hollywood and a bungalow within walking distance of the beach in Aptos.
content: This home was built with dirt excavated from the site, using a construction technique known as SuperAdobe that was developed by Nader Khalili, an Iranian-born American architect who founded the nonprofit organization California Institute of Earth Architecture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Allison Jiang
title: For Gen Z-ers Celebrating Lunar New Year, Hot Pot Offers a Sense of Home
description: The dish, which lets people gather over a single pot and cook together, can foster togetherness among those far from family.
content: As guests trickled into Jenna Zhang and Irene Kim’s apartment in Astoria, Queens, on a recent Saturday evening, no one needed an explanation for the array of raw ingredients before them — the marbled sliced meats; fish tofu and rolled, fried skins; napa cabbage; plump pink rice cakes; and ramen noodles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Golden Peruvian Roasted Chicken With a Brilliant Spicy Sauce
description: Brilliant for its color (an uplifting chartreuse) and its flavor (citrusy, herby and with a clear jalapeño kick).
content: Pollo a la brasa — golden, garlicky chicken roasted on a spit — is a staple across Latin America. To those of us up north, the best known bird is the Peruvian version: crisp-skinned and tender-fleshed, often accompanied by a bright green cilantro-chile sauce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Inger McCabe Elliott, Who Famously Became Con Man’s Victim, Dies at 90
description: She was a successful designer. But she was probably best known for being duped in a scheme that inspired the play “Six Degrees of Separation.”
content: Inger McCabe Elliott, a photographer and designer who, with her husband, was conned at her home in Manhattan by a slick-talking 19-year-old purporting to be Sidney Poitier’s son — an incident that helped inspire John Guare to write his celebrated play “Six Degrees of Separation” — died on Jan. 29 at her home in Manhattan. She was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: British Leader, in Northern Ireland, Relishes a Rare Success
description: A deal bringing disaffected unionists back into the government in Belfast has left Prime Minister Rishi Sunak with one less thing to worry about.
content: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak of Britain took an unaccustomed victory lap on Monday, visiting Belfast to celebrate the restoration of Northern Ireland’s power-sharing government. His ministers struck a deal last week that brought the North’s disaffected unionists back into the territory’s assembly.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Heather Knight
title: California Power Outages Affect More Than 850,000 Customers
description: Utility providers were uncertain when the lights would come back on as outages were reported from Sacramento to just north of Los Angeles.
content: Severe winds of nearly 100 miles per hour lashed parts of California on Sunday, toppling trees and power lines and leaving more than 850,000 homes and businesses across the state without power. Utility providers were uncertain when the lights would go back on.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Baumgaertner
title: After Police Kill Unarmed Black People, Sleep Worsens — but Only for Black People
description: Black people in the U.S. were far more likely to report harmfully low sleep in the months after a killing compared with white people surveyed during that time.
content: Black people in the United States are more likely than white people to report that they do not sleep much, research shows. On average, they live in louder neighborhoods, work longer hours and pick up more late-night shifts — concerning to public health experts, since sleep deprivation is linked to chronic health issues and early death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Hogan
title: Tracy Chapman Returns to the Grammy Stage for ‘Fast Car’ Duet
description: Her duet with Luke Combs was one of her few public performances in recent years.
content: In a major coup for the Grammys, an influential artist who walked away from the spotlight made a grand return to the awards stage on Sunday night: Tracy Chapman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmett Lindner
title: Covering One of California’s ‘Most Dramatic Weather Days’
description: A record-breaking storm swept much of the state on Sunday and stalled over Los Angeles on Monday. Judson Jones, a meteorologist and reporter, kept readers informed of the storm’s path.
content: A powerful storm system moved through California over the weekend. Rainfall was so relentless that the National Weather Service said Sunday was “one of the most dramatic weather days in recent memory.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight and Sam Mondros
title: Blustery Day Leads to Damage in the San Francisco Bay Area
description: Hurricane-force wind gusts brought down trees and power lines.
content: The worst of the storm appeared to be over Sunday night in the San Francisco Bay Area, after rain drenched the region and wind toppled trees throughout the day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Somini Sengupta
title: The Fingerprints on Chile’s Fires and California Floods: El Niño and Warming
description: Two disasters, far apart, show how a dangerous climate cocktail can devastate places known for mild weather.
content: Two far-flung corners of the world, known for their temperate climates, are being buffeted by deadly disasters. Wildfires have killed more than 120 people as they swept the forested hillsides of Chile, and record-breaking rains have swelled rivers and triggered mudslides in Southern California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: How Do I Wear Socks Without Looking Like a Schoolgirl?
description: A reader wonders if socks can shed their association with school uniforms and be used to elevate work and red-carpet apparel.
content: Socks are, as far as I am concerned, one of the most undervalued, and enjoyable, accessories available. Though socks have long held a place of honor in men’s wear as one of the few acceptable ways to express personality, they have played a less meaningful role for women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellyanne Conway
title: Who Should Be Trump’s No. 2?
description: The most important vice-presidential selection question for Mr. Trump is less “who?” than “why?”
content: “Who should President Trump choose for V.P.?” is one of the most popular questions among the political cognoscenti right now. It’s understandable: Donald Trump won Iowa and New Hampshire with more than 50 percent of the vote, after his closest competitors spent sick amounts of time and money trying to persuade voters to move on from him. Polling in Nevada, South Carolina and other upcoming primary and caucus states suggests that Mr. Trump remains in a solid position and that there is little to no math path for the remaining Republican competitor, his former ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: G.O.P. Backlash to Border Deal Reflects Vanishing Ground for a Compromise
description: Republicans demanded a border crackdown but have rejected a bipartisan plan to impose one, underscoring the intractable politics of the issue in an election year.
content: Republicans in Congress who have spent months demanding that any aid to Ukraine be paired with a crackdown against migration into the United States got what they asked for when a bipartisan group of senators released a $118.3 billion agreement that would provide both.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: UNRWA Set to Lose $65 Million, Documents Show
description: The agency, which plays a key role in the humanitarian crisis in Gaza, has received an influx of private donations but not enough to make up for the loss of international funding.
content: The United Nations Relief and Works Agency, the main aid agency in Gaza, is set to lose $65 million by the end of February as donors’ funding cuts begin to kick in, according to internal accounting documents reviewed by The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: They Predict New York Weather, but They’re Not in New York
description: On National Weatherperson’s Day, we look at where our forecasts actually come from.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday, and, because it’s National Weatherperson’s Day, we’ll look at where New York’s forecasts come from. We’ll also find out what happened to a police robot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas and Maggie Astor
title: Biden Meets With Culinary Workers on Eve of Nevada Primary
description: President Biden visited the Vdara Hotel in Las Vegas, where the culinary workers’ union agreed to a contract over the weekend.
content: President Biden met on Monday with members of Nevada’s powerful culinary workers union, after the union averted a planned strike by reaching contract agreements with Las Vegas properties over the weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: boygenius, SZA and ‘Barbie’ Songs Are Among the Early Grammy Winners
description: The tallies for the early awards gave no clear advantage to any artist.
content: Of this year’s 94 Grammy categories, all but nine were given out during a fast-paced, nontelevised ceremony, where some stars (Billie Eilish, Joni Mitchell, boygenius) showed up to accept their awards, but many others (SZA, Michelle Obama) didn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaya Gupta
title: Remnants of a Nuclear Missile Are Found in a Garage
description: The police responded to a call from a U.S. Air Force museum that said a man had offered to donate a Cold War-era missile stored in his late neighbor’s garage.
content: Garages are often cluttered with dusty boxes of heirlooms, untouched gym equipment or a multitude of tools.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: King Charles Is Diagnosed With Cancer
description: Buckingham Palace did not specify the type of cancer but said Britain’s monarch would postpone his public engagements during his treatment.
content: King Charles III has been diagnosed with cancer and is suspending his public engagements to undergo treatment, casting a shadow over a busy reign that began less than 18 months ago after the death of his mother, Queen Elizabeth II.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Rising Costs Have Struck Thin Mints
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, February 5, 2024.
content: “Girl Scouts are not immune to the rising costs of life.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Many Israelis Want Netanyahu Out. But There Is No Simple Path to Do It.
description: There is no clear mechanism to force early elections in Israel. But there are other ways to oust the Israeli prime minister.
content: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel is on his last legs, it is widely believed, and will be forced to relinquish his post once the war against Hamas in Gaza ends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: Jay-Z Takes the Grammys to Task in Awards Speech
description: Jay-Z pointed out the recording academy’s snubs of Black artists, including Beyoncé, while accepting the Dr. Dre Global Impact Award. “We want you to get it right — at least get it close to right,” he said.
content: During a speech at the Grammys on Sunday, Jay-Z criticized the awards show for what he described as its snubs and inconsistencies in giving out honors to Black artists, pointing out that his wife, Beyoncé, has the most Grammys but has never won for album of the year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Edward Moreno
title: What Business Leaders Are Saying About the Red Sea Attacks
description: The Houthi attacks on commercial ships are driving up freight costs and adding delays to journeys, with some companies affected more than others.
content: Recent attacks on commercial ships in the Red Sea by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia have forced companies to pay higher insurance rates or reroute goods around Africa, adding costs and delays that could put a dent in companies’ profit margins and, ultimately, push up prices for consumers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Maggie Haberman and Shane Goldmacher
title: How Trump Uses the Power and Imagery of His Presidency
description: Donald Trump is capitalizing on his unusual status as both a former president and a candidate to twist the race in his favor in ways big and small.
content: Only five days after Donald J. Trump left office, one of his aides emailed a lawyer to request approval of a formal-looking seal for use on statements from the office of the 45th president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caryn Ganz
title: Billy Joel Said He’d Retired From Pop. Here’s What Brought Him Back.
description: The singer and songwriter debuted “Turn the Lights Back On,” his first new song in nearly 20 years, at the Grammy Awards on Sunday.
content: Billy Joel’s first new pop song in nearly two decades was sparked by someone miles from the record business: a Long Island doctor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: New York Distilling Company Moves Down the L Line
description: Visit the new, much larger distiller’s space and sip its new rye, try a red wine that supports prison reform and find a heart-shaped bowl for your Valentine.
content: New York Distilling Company, one of the oldest craft distilleries in New York City, is moving and introducing a new whiskey. Opened in 2011, this distillery made Williamsburg, Brooklyn, its home until last year. In March it will open a new facility, three times the size of the original, in Bushwick. The new distillery will open for 90-minute tours, with a fee and reservations required, beginning on March 1; it will eventually open a new public cocktail bar and tasting room, but it will not be called the Shanty, as it was in Williamsburg. In addition, it is retiring its longstanding Ragtime Rye and replacing it with Jaywalk. The new rye is distilled from Horton rye, a grain varietal with roots dating back to 17th-century New York that the distillery has nurtured, growing it in the Finger Lakes region, over the past eight years. “This is the rye we have been dreaming of for 13 years,” said Allen Katz, the distillery’s co-founder. Three ryes will be bottled under the Jaywalk label: straight rye, a blend of 6-, 7- and 8-year-old ryes and 92 proof ($50 for 750 milliliters); bonded rye, 100 proof ($55 for 750 milliliters); and heirloom rye, cask strength, so named because it’s made from 100 percent Horton rye ($119 for a 700 milliliters). The new whiskies are robust and complex in their flavor, not merely spicy like many ryes. They will all be available starting Feb. 15 from Bottlerocket, in Manhattan, Brooklyn Wine Exchange and Gnarly Vines, in Brooklyn, and online. ROBERT SIMONSON
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Grammy Audience Jumps to 16.9 Million
description: The viewership was the highest for the awards show since the 2020 ceremony, shortly before the pandemic.
content: Award shows are in their rebound era.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Top College Reinstates the SAT
description: Why other schools may follow Dartmouth’s lead.
content: Dartmouth College announced this morning that it would again require applicants to submit standardized test scores, starting next year. It’s a significant development because other selective colleges are now deciding whether to do so. In today’s newsletter, I’ll tell you the story behind Dartmouth’s decision.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Fowler and Rory Doyle
title: Big Companies Cashed In on Mississippi’s Water. Small Towns Paid the Price.
description: They vowed to fix water woes and save cities millions. But a Times investigation found the deals racked up debt and left many worse off than before.
content: In winter 2021, more than 150,000 people living in Jackson, Miss., were left without running water.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: You’ve Just Watched the Super Bowl. What Will You See Next?
description: The TV network that airs the N.F.L. title game wants to retain as many viewers as possible. There are various strategies, with CBS choosing to debut the crime drama “Tracker.”
content: Some of the most precious television real estate comes immediately after the National Football League’s season finale, one of the few programs to still corral a giant audience.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany May and Amy Chang Chien
title: Severe Weather Disrupts Travel in China Ahead of Lunar New Year
description: Hundreds of flights and trains have been canceled as China’s most important holiday approaches, and more bad weather is in the forecast.
content: Snow and freezing rain in China were disrupting travel on Monday and had already caused hundreds of rail and flight cancellations, as millions of people traveled across the country before lunar new year holiday begins this weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Milana Mazaeva
title: Tucker Carlson’s Visit to Russia Draws Speculation of Putin Interview
description: Mr. Carlson has been receiving blanket news coverage from state-run media outlets in Russia since stepping foot in Moscow.
content: Tucker Carlson, the former Fox News host who now has a show on the social network X, has been spotted in Moscow in recent days, leading to speculation in Russia and the United States that he is about to achieve his long-stated goal of interviewing President Vladimir V. Putin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: To Make Blockbuster Shows, Museums Are Turning to Focus Groups
description: To shape its new show about life in the Roman Army, the British Museum put questions to members of the public. Other institutions are also using the same technique.
content: Last January, 14 members of the British public entered a wood-paneled room in the back of the British Museum for a secret presentation. They were there to learn about an exhibition still in development, which the museum wanted kept under wraps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Will Taylor Swift Cry if Kansas City Loses? You Can Bet on It.
description: While casino gambling focuses on the Super Bowl itself, online sports books are flooded with options on what Ms. Swift will wear, how she’ll celebrate and more.
content: The Super Bowl always draws crowds to betting windows and online sports books, but some of the most talked about action this year will leave a blank space in Las Vegas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: We Might Be One Step Closer to Saving America’s Amazon
description: A federal judge’s ruling may hold a glimmer of hope for the Mobile-Tensaw Delta.
content: Drifting in the channels of the Mobile-Tensaw Delta, it’s easy to imagine that you are in some deeply isolated wilderness, far from the motors of man. Even when the city of Mobile, Ala., is visible in the distance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron, Jon Pareles, Ben Sisario and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2024 Grammys
description: Young women brought the drama, Jay-Z surprised with a barbed speech and heroes long absent from the show’s stage made welcome returns at the 66th annual awards.
content: The most awards at the 66th annual Grammys went to Phoebe Bridgers, who picked up three with her band boygenius and one for a feature on a SZA song. SZA, who came into the night with the most nominations, was shut out of the biggest honors — for album (which went to Taylor Swift’s “Midnights”), record (Miley Cyrus’s “Flowers”) and song (Billie Eilish’s “What Was I Made For?”) — but took home three trophies. Victoria Monét was named best new artist, and Swift’s album win broke a Grammy record for the category. The show was particularly joyous, slick and thoughtful, featuring several striking performances and a few raw acceptance speeches. All in all, it captured pop music as it actually is — centerless, and subject to change at any moment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: ‘True Detective’ Season 4, Episode 4 Recap: The Monster Under the Bed
description: Danvers wrestles with her demons. Navarro does, too, but hers appear to be of a different sort.
content: There’s a classic bit on “The Simpsons” where a panel of children are seated as a focus group for “The Itchy & Scratchy Show” and asked what they want to see from the long-running cartoon, which has started to flag in the ratings. After an exasperating series of responses, the moderator sums up his findings: “So you want a realistic, down-to-earth show that’s completely off the wall and swarming with magic robots?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Nikki Haley Raises $16.5 Million, Fueling Her Fight Against Trump
description: Ms. Haley faces long odds against Donald J. Trump in the next major Republican nominating contest, but has signaled her intent to stay in.
content: Officials with Nikki Haley’s campaign said Monday that she had raised $16.5 million in January, her biggest monthly fund-raising total to date, adding a new infusion of cash to the $14.6 million her campaign brought into the new year to keep the nomination fight with Donald J. Trump going.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stefanos Chen and Ahmed Gaber
title: What’s Behind This $10 Chicken Over Rice? An $18,000 Permit.
description: Blame rising costs, shrunken crowds and a black-market permit trade. Chicken over rice costs $10 at the Halal Plates, a cart in Lower Manhattan, up from $6 prepandemic.
content: But Mr. Mousa focused on one number: 3,892. That was his position on a New York City food vendor waiting list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Goodbye Mostly Mozart, Hello Festival Orchestra of Lincoln Center
description: The renamed ensemble will present a mix of new and old in its first season under the conductor Jonathon Heyward.
content: Last summer, Lincoln Center bid farewell to the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, a fixture of the city’s cultural scene since 1973, saying it was time to reimagine the ensemble for a modern and more inclusive age.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Killer Mike Calls His Grammys Arrest a ‘Speed Bump’
description: The artist was arrested on a misdemeanor battery charge after winning awards for best rap album, best rap performance and best rap song.
content: Hours after he was released from police custody in Los Angeles after police said he was involved in a physical altercation on Grammys night, the rapper Killer Mike said in a radio interview Monday morning that the arrest was a mere blip in a triumphant night when he won three Grammys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Hogan
title: Victoria Monét Is Named the Grammys’ Best New Artist
description: Monet, once a behind-the-scenes hitmaker for other performers, was nominated for seven Grammys. Her full-length debut, “Jaguar II,” won for best R&B album.
content: In an eclectic field, honors for best new artist — one of the Grammys’ four most coveted awards — went to the pop and R&B singer-songwriter Victoria Monét.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: U.S. Plans More Strikes, and Storm Slams Los Angeles
description: Plus, Taylor Swift makes history.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Santul Nerkar and Sydney Ember
title: Boeing, Still Recovering From Max 8 Crashes, Faces a New Crisis
description: The incident on an Alaska Airlines 737 Max 9 plane is likely to increase Boeing’s costs and scrutiny of the manufacturer by regulators, airlines and travelers.
content: After two deadly crashes involving its best-selling 737 Max 8 planes five years ago, Boeing spent billions of dollars to make its products safer and repair its reputation. Now, the company is again confronting a wave of uncertainty and costs after a harrowing incident involving a different 737 jet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Facing Another Boeing Crisis, the F.A.A. Takes a Harder Line
description: The latest crisis involving a 737 Max jet is once again prompting scrutiny of the Federal Aviation Administration’s oversight of Boeing.
content: When a Boeing 737 Max 8 crashed off the coast of Indonesia in 2018, killing all 189 people on board, the Federal Aviation Administration allowed other Max planes to keep flying. Less than five months later, in early 2019, another Max 8 crashed in Ethiopia, killing 157 more people. Even then, days passed before the agency halted the planes from flying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: Fake and Explicit Images of Taylor Swift Started on 4chan, Study Says
description: The people on 4chan who created the images of Ms. Swift thought of it as a sort of game, the researchers said.
content: Images of Taylor Swift that had been generated by artificial intelligence and had spread widely across social media in late January probably originated as part of a recurring challenge on one of the internet’s most notorious message boards, according to a new report.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Do You Know Where These Apocalyptic Novels Are Set?
description: Try this short quiz to see how many fictional disasters you remember from your reading.
content: Try this short quiz to see how many fictional disasters you remember from your reading.

author: By Leanne Abraham, Zach Levitt and Elena Shao
title: See Where Heavy Rainfall Deluged California
description: Heavy rainfall pounded Southern California and much of the state on Monday, flooding roads and causing dangerous landslides.
content: Heavy rainfall pounded Southern California and much of the state on Monday, flooding roads and causing dangerous landslides.

title: Heavy Snow in China Disrupts Holiday Travel
description: Footage from China Central Television, a state media outlet, showed vehicles moving slowly on highways blanketed by snow as the Lunar New Year travel rush begins.
